ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Speaking and writing the czech language
I furthered my understanding and fluency in Czech this fall. I also felt like I learned a lot about the country and the people there.
I have gained a broader knowledge of the Czech language.
I continued my education in the czech language and became more confident in speaking and reading czech
I learned about the culture and language of The Czech Republic.
I learned how to read Czech better and how to understand the language as a whole.

I learned a lot about the language, culture, and customs of the Czech Republic and I feel confident that I could hold conversations and navigate the country if I were to go on a trip there, study there, or work there in the future.

We learned many topics in Czech 130 but the majority of the course revolves around speaking Czech rather than reading and writing in Czech. We learned about conjugation and how to put words in to their proper tense as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course could be improved by starting with learning vocabulary and then moving on to grammar and reading/speaking. I felt like sometimes, in an effort to develop our fluency, were we expected to understand words and conjugations that I didn't remember learning. Maybe this is the best way to develop fluency, but I felt like I was sometimes overwhelmed by some of the material we would cover in class.
There were only strengths, no weaknesses. My favorite class this semester!

Professor Von kunes creates a great learning environment for learning the difficult czech language. She is very patient with students and goes over material multiple times to solidify the knowledge for students.
The course does a great job teaching all sorts of things about the Czech Republic in interesting ways that keep that class attentive.
I would have liked to become more of a conversationalist with the language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, I think Czech is a very unique language that most people do not have the opportunity to study because there are so few great Czech professors like KVK. The option to take Czech at Yale sets the school apart from most other institutions in the country and provides an opportunity granted to very few college students.
Yes, it is a fantastic language with an amazing professor.
I would definitely recommend this course. After taking The first two levels of czech, continuing to the third course is a excellent way to continue the knowledge of czech.
Yes
Yes, Czech is a cool language.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student because I feel like Professor Von Kunes does a great job teaching the course and she makes it very very interesting.
Absolutely, Professor Von Kunes does a fantastic job making a very difficult language seem much more manageable.
